canonical_explanation.text:
The animal kingdom encompasses an enormous diversity of organisms classified on the basis of body organisation, symmetry, coelom type, segmentation, and the presence or absence of a notochord. Animals are broadly divided into non-chordates (Porifera through Hemichordata) and chordates, which possess a notochord at some stage of life. Non-chordates include phyla such as Porifera (sponges), Cnidaria (coelenterates), Platyhelminthes (flatworms), Aschelminthes (roundworms), Annelida (segmented worms), Arthropoda (the largest phylum), Mollusca, Echinodermata, and Hemichordata.

Phylum Chordata is characterised by the presence of a notochord, a dorsal hollow nerve cord, and paired pharyngeal gill slits. Chordates are subdivided into Urochordata, Cephalochordata, and Vertebrata. Vertebrates are further classified into classes Cyclostomata (jawless fish), Chondrichthyes (cartilaginous fish), Osteichthyes (bony fish), Amphibia, Reptilia, Aves, and Mammalia, each distinguished by specific features such as type of skeleton, respiratory organs, heart chambers, body covering, and mode of reproduction.
rules: Levels of organisation: cellular (Porifera), tissue (Cnidaria), organ (Platyhelminthes), organ-system (Annelida onward).
Symmetry: asymmetrical (most sponges), radial (Cnidaria, Echinodermata adults), bilateral (most other phyla).
Germ layers: diploblastic (Cnidaria) vs triploblastic (Platyhelminthes onward).
Coelom types: acoelomate (Platyhelminthes), pseudocoelomate (Aschelminthes), coelomate (Annelida onward).
Non-chordates lack a notochord; chordates possess it at least during embryonic development.
Arthropoda is the largest animal phylum; insects form the majority.
Echinoderms are exclusively marine and show radial symmetry in adults but bilateral symmetry in larvae.
Chondrichthyes have a cartilaginous endoskeleton; Osteichthyes have a bony endoskeleton.
Amphibians are the first tetrapods to colonise land but depend on water for reproduction.
Reptiles are the first truly terrestrial vertebrates with internal fertilisation and shelled eggs.
Aves are warm-blooded with feathers, pneumatic bones, and a four-chambered heart.
Mammals are viviparous (except monotremes), possess mammary glands, hair, and a diaphragm.

questions.question_text: Which level of organisation is exhibited by members of Phylum Porifera?
questions.explanation_correct: Poriferans (sponges) show cellular level of organisation; their cells are loosely aggregated and do not form true tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tissue level is seen in Cnidaria, organ level in Platyhelminthes, and organ-system level from Annelida onward. Porifera lacks true tissues.

questions.question_text: Bilateral symmetry means that the body can be divided into two identical halves through:

options.text: Any plane passing through the central axis
Only one specific plane (median sagittal plane)
Two planes at right angles to each other

questions.explanation_correct: In bilateral symmetry, the body can be divided into two equal halves only through the median sagittal plane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A describes radial symmetry where any plane through the central axis gives identical halves. Bilateral symmetry requires exactly one specific plane.

questions.question_text: Animals in which the body cavity is not lined by mesoderm are called:
questions.explanation_correct: In pseudocoelomates, the body cavity is present but it is not lined by mesoderm on both sides; mesoderm is present only as scattered pouches between ectoderm and endoderm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acoelomates have no body cavity at all. Coelomates have a true coelom completely lined by mesoderm. Pseudocoelomates have a cavity not fully lined by mesoderm.

questions.question_text: Ascaris has a body cavity between the body wall and the gut, but this cavity is not lined by mesoderm on the inner side. This type of body cavity is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Ascaris belongs to Phylum Aschelminthes, which are pseudocoelomates. Their body cavity is not lined by mesoderm on the inner side (gut side).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A true coelom is fully lined by mesoderm. Haemocoel is the blood-filled body cavity in arthropods. Spongocoel is the central cavity of sponges.

questions.question_text: An animal is triploblastic, coelomate, and shows metamerism. It most likely belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: Annelids are triploblastic, coelomate, and exhibit true metamerism (segmentation). Platyhelminthes are acoelomate and Aschelminthes are pseudocoelomate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Platyhelminthes lack a coelom. Aschelminthes are pseudocoelomate. Cnidaria are diploblastic. Only Annelida combines all three features — triploblastic, coelomate, and metameric.

questions.question_text: Echinoderms have radial symmetry as adults but bilateral symmetry as larvae. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Echinoderms develop bilateral symmetry in the larval stage but acquire radial symmetry in the adult stage. Since radial symmetry is derived from bilateral, it is called secondary radial symmetry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Primary radial symmetry is seen in cnidarians that are radial from the beginning. Echinoderms transition from bilateral to radial, making it secondary.

questions.question_text: Which of the following combinations is correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Platyhelminthes are triploblastic (three germ layers) and acoelomate (no body cavity). This is the correct combination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cnidaria are diploblastic, not triploblastic. Aschelminthes are triploblastic, not diploblastic. Annelida are coelomate, not pseudocoelomate.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a basis used for animal classification?
questions.explanation_correct: Mode of nutrition (autotrophic or heterotrophic) is primarily used to distinguish plants from animals, not as a basis for classifying animals into phyla. The standard bases include symmetry, coelom, germ layers, segmentation, notochord, and digestive/circulatory system patterns.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Body symmetry, nature of coelom, and digestive system patterns are all standard bases for animal classification as described in NCERT. Mode of nutrition is not a primary criterion within the animal kingdom.

questions.question_text: Assertion (A): Cnidarians are said to be diploblastic. Reason (R): Their body wall is made of two layers — ectoderm and endoderm with an undifferentiated mesoglea in between.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Cnidarians are diploblastic because they have only two embryonic germ layers (ectoderm and endoderm). The mesoglea between them is a non-cellular, undifferentiated layer, not a true mesoderm. The reason correctly explains why they are diploblastic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are factually correct, and the reason directly explains the assertion. The undifferentiated mesoglea is what distinguishes diploblastic from triploblastic organisms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following animals shows organ-system level of body organisation?
questions.explanation_correct: Nereis belongs to Phylum Annelida which shows organ-system level of organisation. Sycon (Porifera) shows cellular level, Hydra (Cnidaria) tissue level, and Planaria (Platyhelminthes) organ level.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sycon is a sponge with cellular level. Hydra has tissue level. Planaria has organ level. From Annelida onward, animals display organ-system level of organisation.

questions.question_text: A student observes an animal that is triploblastic, acoelomate, dorsoventrally flattened, and has flame cells. The animal most likely belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: Platyhelminthes are triploblastic, acoelomate, dorsoventrally flattened, and possess flame cells for excretion. All the described features match this phylum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aschelminthes are pseudocoelomate and cylindrical. Annelida are coelomate. Cnidaria are diploblastic. The combination of acoelomate body, dorsoventral flattening, and flame cells is unique to Platyhelminthes.

questions.question_text: Segmentation in which the external divisions correspond to internal divisions is called:
questions.explanation_correct: True metamerism (metameric segmentation) refers to the serial repetition of body segments where external divisions correspond to internal organ divisions. This is seen in Annelida and Arthropoda.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pseudometamerism refers to superficial external segmentation without corresponding internal segmentation (as in tapeworms). Tagmatisation is the fusion of segments into functional groups.

questions.question_text: The water canal system is a characteristic feature of which phylum?
questions.explanation_correct: The water canal system (consisting of ostia, spongocoel, and osculum) is a defining feature of Porifera. Water flows through it for food gathering, respiration, and waste removal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Echinodermata possess a water vascular system (different from the water canal system). Cnidaria and Mollusca do not have a water canal system.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organisms possesses cnidoblasts (nematocysts)?
questions.explanation_correct: Obelia belongs to Phylum Cnidaria. Cnidoblasts (stinging cells containing nematocysts) are the hallmark of cnidarians and are used for defence and capturing prey.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Taenia (Platyhelminthes), Ascaris (Aschelminthes), and Nereis (Annelida) do not possess cnidoblasts. This feature is exclusive to Cnidaria.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the largest animal phylum?
questions.explanation_correct: Arthropoda is the largest animal phylum, comprising over 80% of known animal species. It includes insects, crustaceans, arachnids, and myriapods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mollusca is the second largest phylum. Annelida and Chordata have far fewer species than Arthropoda.

questions.question_text: An animal has a soft unsegmented body covered by a calcareous shell and a muscular foot for locomotion. It uses a rasping organ called radula for feeding. This animal belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: A soft unsegmented body, calcareous shell, muscular foot, and radula are characteristic features of Phylum Mollusca. Examples include Pila (apple snail) and Unio (freshwater mussel).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arthropods have a chitinous exoskeleton and jointed legs. Echinoderms have a water vascular system. Annelids are segmented. The described features are unique to Mollusca.

questions.question_text: The water vascular system used for locomotion, food capture, and respiration is found in:
questions.explanation_correct: The water vascular system (ambulacral system) is a unique feature of Echinodermata. It consists of tube feet that aid in locomotion, food capture, and respiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Porifera have a water canal system (not water vascular system). Cnidaria and Mollusca lack a water vascular system. This ambulacral system is exclusive to echinoderms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly matches the phylum with its excretory structure?
questions.explanation_correct: Annelids excrete waste through nephridia. Platyhelminthes use flame cells, Arthropoda use Malpighian tubules (in insects) or green glands (in crustaceans), not the other way around.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Platyhelminthes have flame cells (not Malpighian tubules). Arthropoda have Malpighian tubules or green glands (not flame cells). Annelida — nephridia is the correct match.

questions.question_text: Which non-chordate phylum is exclusively marine?
questions.explanation_correct: Echinodermata is an exclusively marine phylum. All echinoderms like starfish, sea urchins, and sea cucumbers are found only in ocean habitats.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arthropoda, Annelida, and Mollusca all have members found in marine, freshwater, and terrestrial habitats. Only Echinodermata is restricted to marine environments.

questions.question_text:
Match the following organisms with their respective phyla:
(i) Sycon — (a) Annelida
(ii) Asterias — (b) Porifera
(iii) Nereis — (c) Arthropoda
(iv) Apis — (d) Echinodermata
questions.explanation_correct: Sycon is a sponge (Porifera), Asterias (starfish) is an echinoderm (Echinodermata), Nereis (sandworm) is an annelid (Annelida), and Apis (honeybee) is an arthropod (Arthropoda).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matching is: Sycon-Porifera, Asterias-Echinodermata, Nereis-Annelida, Apis-Arthropoda. Only option A has all four correct.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about Phylum Aschelminthes is INCORRECT?
questions.explanation_correct: Aschelminthes (roundworms) do NOT show true metamerism. They have a cylindrical, unsegmented body. True metamerism is characteristic of Annelida.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aschelminthes are indeed pseudocoelomate, triploblastic, and dioecious (separate sexes). However, they are unsegmented and do not display metamerism.

questions.question_text: Balanoglossus is placed in which phylum?
questions.explanation_correct: Balanoglossus (tongue worm) is a hemichordate. Hemichordata was earlier considered a sub-phylum of Chordata but is now placed as a separate phylum close to chordates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Though Balanoglossus has a structure resembling a notochord (stomochord), it is now classified under Hemichordata, not Chordata. It is not an echinoderm or annelid.

questions.question_text: Taenia (tapeworm) belongs to which phylum?
questions.explanation_correct: Taenia (tapeworm) is a flatworm belonging to Phylum Platyhelminthes. It is an endoparasite found in the intestine of vertebrates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aschelminthes include roundworms like Ascaris. Annelida includes segmented worms. Cnidaria includes jellyfish and corals. Taenia is a flatworm — Platyhelminthes.

questions.question_text: Jointed appendages are a characteristic feature of:
questions.explanation_correct: The name Arthropoda literally means 'jointed feet'. Jointed appendages along with a chitinous exoskeleton are the hallmark features of this phylum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Annelids have parapodia (not jointed appendages). Molluscs have a muscular foot. Echinoderms have tube feet. Jointed appendages are exclusive to Arthropoda.

questions.question_text: An organism exhibits polymorphism, has cnidoblasts, and shows both polyp and medusa forms. It belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: Polymorphism, cnidoblasts, and alternation of polyp and medusa forms are all characteristic of Cnidaria (e.g., Obelia).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Porifera lack cnidoblasts and polymorphism in that sense. Platyhelminthes and Arthropoda do not have cnidoblasts or medusa/polyp body forms. These features are unique to Cnidaria.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of phylum Chordata?

options.text: Notochord present at some stage of life

questions.explanation_correct: A ventral solid nerve cord is a characteristic of non-chordates (e.g., Annelida, Arthropoda). Chordates possess a dorsal hollow nerve cord.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Notochord, dorsal hollow nerve cord, and paired pharyngeal gill slits are the three defining features of Chordata. A ventral solid nerve cord is found in non-chordates.

questions.question_text: In Urochordata, the notochord is present in:

options.text: The tail region of the larva only
The head to tail region throughout life

questions.explanation_correct: In urochordates (e.g., Ascidia), the notochord is present only in the tail region of the larval stage and is lost in adults. Hence they are also called Tunicata.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In urochordates, the notochord is restricted to the larval tail. In adults, the notochord disappears. Cephalochordates retain the notochord from head to tail throughout life.

questions.question_text: Branchiostoma (Amphioxus) belongs to which sub-phylum?
questions.explanation_correct: Branchiostoma (Amphioxus) belongs to Cephalochordata. In cephalochordates, the notochord extends from head to tail and persists throughout life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Urochordata includes tunicates like Ascidia. Vertebrata includes animals with a vertebral column. Hemichordata is a separate phylum. Amphioxus is the classic example of Cephalochordata.

questions.question_text: Which of the following sub-phyla of Chordata has members where the notochord is replaced by a vertebral column in the adult?
questions.explanation_correct: In Vertebrata, the embryonic notochord is replaced by a vertebral column (backbone) in the adult. This is one of the defining features of vertebrates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In Urochordata, the notochord is lost in adults. In Cephalochordata, the notochord persists throughout life. Only in Vertebrata is the notochord replaced by a vertebral column.

questions.question_text: A marine organism with a leathery tunic, basket-like pharynx with gill slits, and a notochord only in its larval tail is most likely a member of:
questions.explanation_correct: The leathery tunic, basket-like pharynx with gill slits, and notochord restricted to the larval tail are all features of Urochordata (e.g., Ascidia or Herdmania).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cephalochordates retain the notochord throughout life. Vertebrates have a vertebral column. The tunic and larval notochord indicate Urochordata.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a feature that distinguishes Vertebrata from other sub-phyla of Chordata?
questions.explanation_correct: All chordates share notochord, pharyngeal gill slits, and dorsal nerve cord. The cranium (brain box) protecting the brain is unique to vertebrates, which is why they are also called Craniata.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Notochord, pharyngeal gill slits, and dorsal nerve cord are common to all chordates. Only the cranium and vertebral column distinguish Vertebrata from Urochordata and Cephalochordata.

questions.question_text: Assertion (A): Urochordates and Cephalochordates are often called protochordates. Reason (R): They possess a notochord but lack a true vertebral column and cranium.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Urochordates and cephalochordates are called protochordates (primitive chordates) because they possess a notochord but lack a vertebral column and cranium, which are features of true vertebrates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are correct, and the reason directly explains why they are termed protochordates — they have chordate features but lack vertebrate specialisations.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs of organisms belongs to the same sub-phylum?
questions.explanation_correct: Herdmania and Ascidia are both urochordates (Tunicata). Branchiostoma is a cephalochordate, and Petromyzon is a vertebrate (Cyclostomata).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ascidia and Herdmania both belong to Urochordata. The other pairs mix organisms from different sub-phyla.

questions.question_text: Which feature is shared by Hemichordata and Chordata?
questions.explanation_correct: Hemichordates share pharyngeal gill slits with chordates. However, the hemichordate 'stomochord' is not a true notochord, and their nerve cord is not dorsal and hollow like in chordates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hemichordates have a stomochord, not a true notochord. They have a nerve cord that is partly dorsal but not consistently hollow. The pharyngeal gill slits are the shared feature.

questions.question_text: Which class of vertebrates has a cartilaginous endoskeleton?
questions.explanation_correct: Chondrichthyes (cartilaginous fish) have an endoskeleton made entirely of cartilage. Examples include sharks, rays, and skates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Osteichthyes have a bony endoskeleton. Cyclostomata have a cartilaginous skeleton but are jawless and distinct from Chondrichthyes. Amphibians have a bony endoskeleton.

questions.question_text: Which class of vertebrates are the first to show a three-chambered heart?
questions.explanation_correct: Amphibians have a three-chambered heart (two atria and one ventricle). Fish (both Chondrichthyes and Osteichthyes) have a two-chambered heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both Chondrichthyes and Osteichthyes have a two-chambered heart. The three-chambered heart first appears in Amphibia. Reptilia also have three chambers (except crocodiles with four).

questions.question_text: Pneumatic bones are a characteristic feature of:
questions.explanation_correct: Aves (birds) possess pneumatic bones — hollow bones with air cavities that reduce body weight and assist in flight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pneumatic bones are an adaptation for flight and are found exclusively in birds. Reptiles, amphibians, and mammals do not have pneumatic bones.

questions.question_text: Petromyzon (lamprey) belongs to which class?
questions.explanation_correct: Petromyzon (lamprey) belongs to class Cyclostomata. Cyclostomes are jawless vertebrates with a circular sucking mouth and are ectoparasites on fish.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cyclostomata includes jawless fish like lampreys and hagfish. Chondrichthyes and Osteichthyes have jaws. Petromyzon is not an amphibian.

questions.question_text: A cold-blooded vertebrate with scales, lays eggs with a tough shell on land, and breathes through lungs. It belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: Cold-blooded (poikilothermic), scaly skin, eggs with tough shell laid on land, and lung respiration are all features of Reptilia. Examples include lizards, snakes, turtles, and crocodiles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amphibians are cold-blooded but lack scales and lay eggs in water. Birds are warm-blooded. Fish live in water. The described features point to Reptilia.

questions.question_text: Which vertebrate class has a four-chambered heart and is warm-blooded but does NOT give birth to live young (in most cases)?
questions.explanation_correct: Aves (birds) are warm-blooded (homeothermic) with a four-chambered heart and are oviparous (lay eggs). Mammals are also warm-blooded with a four-chambered heart but are mostly viviparous.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mammals are mostly viviparous (give birth to live young). Reptilia are cold-blooded with a three-chambered heart (except crocodiles). Birds fit all the described criteria.

questions.question_text: Which of the following fish has a bony endoskeleton and an air bladder for buoyancy?
questions.explanation_correct: Labeo (rohu) is a bony fish (Osteichthyes) with a bony endoskeleton and an air bladder that helps in buoyancy regulation. Sharks, sawfish, and electric rays are cartilaginous fish (Chondrichthyes) that lack an air bladder.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scoliodon, Pristis, and Torpedo are all Chondrichthyes with cartilaginous skeletons and no air bladder. Only Labeo (an Osteichthyes) has a bony skeleton and air bladder.

questions.question_text: Which class of vertebrates shows the phenomenon of metamorphosis?
questions.explanation_correct: Amphibians undergo metamorphosis — the aquatic larva (tadpole) transforms into the terrestrial adult. This involves changes in respiration (gills to lungs), limb development, and tail resorption.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fish, reptiles, and mammals do not undergo metamorphosis. This developmental transformation from aquatic larva to terrestrial adult is characteristic of Amphibia.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an egg-laying mammal?
questions.explanation_correct: Ornithorhynchus (platypus) is a monotreme — an egg-laying mammal. Monotremes lay eggs but still possess mammary glands and hair, which are defining mammalian features.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Macropus is a marsupial (pouched mammal). Pteropus and Balaenoptera are placental mammals. Only Ornithorhynchus (and echidna) are egg-laying mammals (monotremes).

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about Chondrichthyes is correct?

options.text: They have an air bladder for buoyancy
They have placoid scales and a ventral mouth
They have operculum covering the gills

questions.explanation_correct: Chondrichthyes have placoid scales (tiny tooth-like scales) and a ventrally positioned mouth. They lack an air bladder and operculum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chondrichthyes lack an air bladder (they have to swim continuously to avoid sinking). Their mouth is ventral, not terminal. They lack operculum — gill slits are separate. Placoid scales and ventral mouth are correct.

questions.question_text: Which of the following vertebrates has a three-chambered heart with an incomplete inter-ventricular septum?
questions.explanation_correct: Most reptiles like the lizard have a three-chambered heart with an incomplete inter-ventricular septum. Crocodiles are the exception among reptiles with a four-chambered heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frogs have a three-chambered heart without a septum in the ventricle. Crocodiles have a four-chambered heart. Pigeons (Aves) have a four-chambered heart. Lizards have three chambers with an incomplete septum.

questions.question_text: Which of the following features is common to both Aves and Mammalia?
questions.explanation_correct: Both Aves and Mammalia are warm-blooded (homeothermic) and possess a four-chambered heart with complete separation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Feathers are exclusive to birds. Mammary glands are exclusive to mammals. Most birds are oviparous. The shared features are warm-bloodedness and a four-chambered heart.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Mammalia?
questions.explanation_correct: The diaphragm is a muscular partition unique to mammals that separates the thoracic and abdominal cavities and aids in breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Feathers belong to birds. Scales are found in reptiles and fish. Mammals are homeothermic (warm-blooded), not poikilothermic. The diaphragm is unique to mammals.

questions.question_text:
Match the vertebrate class with its correct example:
(i) Cyclostomata — (a) Hippocampus
(ii) Chondrichthyes — (b) Petromyzon
(iii) Osteichthyes — (c) Ichthyophis
(iv) Amphibia — (d) Trygon
questions.explanation_correct: Petromyzon (lamprey) — Cyclostomata; Trygon (stingray) — Chondrichthyes; Hippocampus (seahorse) — Osteichthyes; Ichthyophis (limbless amphibian) — Amphibia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petromyzon is a jawless fish (Cyclostomata), Trygon is a cartilaginous fish (Chondrichthyes), Hippocampus is a bony fish (Osteichthyes), and Ichthyophis is an amphibian (Apoda).

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs of animals are both poikilothermic?
questions.explanation_correct: Frogs (Amphibia) and crocodiles (Reptilia) are both poikilothermic (cold-blooded). Their body temperature varies with the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pigeons (Aves), whales (Mammalia), and bats (Mammalia) are all homeothermic (warm-blooded). Only frogs and crocodiles are both cold-blooded.

questions.question_text: Swim bladder is absent in Chondrichthyes. How do they maintain buoyancy?

options.text: By storing air in their lungs
By the presence of large oil-filled liver

questions.explanation_correct: Chondrichthyes lack a swim bladder. They maintain buoyancy with the help of their large liver filled with oil (squalene), which is lighter than water, and they must swim continuously.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chondrichthyes do not have lungs for air storage. They lack operculum (which covers gills in bony fish). Pneumatic bones are found in birds. The oil-filled liver aids buoyancy.
